qas.question: What non-linguistic developments influence the status of a language?
What dialect is the language Romansh similar to?
What language are Mandarin and Cantonese sometimes considered dialects of?
Why might Mandarin and Cantonese not be regarded as dialects?
What is the status of language solely determined by?
Along with alpine dialects, what else is the status of language determined by?
What types of development help to determine the status of Mandarin?
Lombardic is recognized as a language despite being close to which alpine dialect?
Which variations of the Chinese language have mutual intelligibility?

context: The status of "language" is not solely determined by <b4_0>linguistic criteria<b4_0/>, but it is also the result of a <a0_0><b5_0><b6_0>historical and political<b6_0/><a0_0/> development<b5_0/>. <b7_0>Romansh<b7_0/> came to be a written language, and therefore it is recognized as a language, even though it is very close to the <a1_0>Lombardic alpine<a1_0/> dialects. An opposite example is the case of <a2_0>Chinese<a2_0/>, whose variations such as <b8_0>Mandarin and Cantonese<b8_0/> are often called dialects and not languages, despite their <a3_0>mutual unintelligibility<a3_0/>.
